subtitle: We have now released issue 3 of the New Thinking Allowed magazine.
Download it for free at newthinkingallowed.org.
New Thinking Allowed is a non-profit endeavor.
Your contributions to the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation make a meaningful difference in
our ability to produce new videos.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we're going to explore the life and work
of Friedrich Jürgensen, one of the pioneers
in the field of electronic voice phenomena,
also known as instrumental transcommunication,
or ITC.
My guest is Anabela Cardoso, a former Portuguese
diplomat having served as council general
in Spain, France and the United States, as
well as charge d'affaires in Japan and India.
She is author of Electronic Voices – Contact
with Another Dimension, Electronic Contact
with the Dead – What the Voices Tell Us, and Glimpses of Another World – Impressions
and Reflections of an EVP Operator.
Her newest book, which we'll be focusing on today, is the English translation of the
Swedish book by Anders Leopold called Friedel's
Conversations with the Dead, the fascinating
story of Friedrich Jürgensen, pioneer of EVP.
Anabela lives in Spain and now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome Anabela.
It's a real pleasure to be with you.
It's been two years since our last interviews.
Thank you, Jeff.
Of course it's a pleasure, it's always a pleasure to be with you.
You are such a cheerful person.
It's enjoyable to be with you, always.
Thank you.
I know your lifelong passion or your professional
passion since you left the Diplomatic Service
has been EVP.
You're not just a scholar of the field, which
you are, you are an experiencer, and Friedrich
Jürgensen, who we'll be talking about today,
is probably not as well known today as you
are in the field, but he's one of the pioneers and a big inspiration to you.
Indeed, that is absolutely, absolutely true.
And that is perhaps the main reason why, as well as Anders Leopold, wanted this book
in English so that he would be and take the,
how do I say, the glory, let's put it between
inverted commas, but the merit that he certainly
deserves, not only because of his work with
the voices, but because of his life, because
of everything he forgot about to devote himself
to these extraordinary voices that spoke with him through the radio and the tapes.
So it's necessary to be very brave to do this
because his career as an artist was a wonderful
career.
I mean, he was a very well-known painter.
That's the reason why the Vatican recruited him to paint in the place that was supposed
to be Peter's tomb and the Pope at the time,
Pius XII, because of his merits as a painter.
And he had sang at the Scala di Milano and all these things.
He had made movies.
He made several at the end of his life, maybe six or seven.
Some of them acclaimed movies.
I couldn't recall all the titles, but it was a number of them.
And he put all that aside to devote his life
to the voices which then, as today, were not
understood properly and properly accepted, let's put it this way.
In terms of acceptance, I think one of the
most important facts is that the Pope himself
acknowledged that these voices are probably evidence of survival after death, something
which, to my understanding, the Catholic Church
is normally very reluctant to talk about.
These days, I do not know what the position of
the Church is, but at the time of Jürgensen,
there were two Popes.
Let's start by here.
Pope Pius XII, of whom he also painted several
portraits, and the Pope that followed, Paul VI
Even I saw this Pope in Italy, in Castel Gandolf,
when I was a young girl of 19, and I was a
tourist guide, and took there some American people who were my clients.
I worked with American Express, and I was a student at the university in Lisbon.
Anyway, I saw this Pope, which is the Pope that became Jürgensen's friend, and yes,
as you said, they both acknowledged the
voices directly, I mean, the Popes themselves.
The first Pope, Pius XII, which is the Pope of the Second World War, who have not very
good reputation, but how correct this interpretation is or not, I don't know.
I'm not an expert in the Catholic Church or any
other church, but Pius XII told two scientists,
one of very good scientists in Italy, one of them, Father Agostino Gemelli, of whom
now the most important hospital in Italy, he founded it, as he founded the Catholic
University of Milano, Agostino Gemelli.
If you remember, when the Popes get ill, they are taken to this hospital.
It's called Polyclinic Gemelli or something like this.
This comes from this priest, who was just cleaning Gregorian chants with a colleague,
Father Ernetti, who was an expert in music, and suddenly a voice appeared recorded on
their tapes.
They were cleaning the tapes or the harmonics or something of this kind.
And Gemelli, who is one of the great scientists
of his time in Italy, Father Agostino Gemelli,
recognized immediately his father's voice,
calling him by his pet name, which was Zucchini.
Zucchini means zucchini.
It's the same in English, if I'm not mistaken,
Zucchini one says in English, isn't it?
This pumpkin, the green pumpkin, longish one.
Yes, a vegetable, a squash.
Squash, the green one.
And this voice said, he had said, Papa, help
me, because the tape was breaking all the
time, because it's the reel-to-reel, reel-to-reel tapes.
And Gemelli, this very important scientist, I stress this because this is important to
say how important he was, said, well, this is my father's voice here in the middle of
the Gregorian chants.
And they listened and re-listened, and there it was, and there it was.
And they insisted, and then they started speaking into the air.
And the voice replied, of course it's me,
don't you recognize me any longer or something
like this?
And they were very scared, because at the time, this was September 1952.
That was the time when spiritism, as it was called in Europe, not spiritualism, as you
know, spiritualism is of the Anglo-Saxon countries,
the United States, Great Britain, and so on.
In the rest of Europe, from Allan Kardec, it was spiritism.
So they were afraid, because the church had a very strict position about spiritism, and
they were scared with this voice.
So they decided to take it and tell the Pope
what had happened, and this was Pius XII.
And they said, well, this happened, and we want to let you know, Father.
And the Pope said, well, don't be afraid, this has nothing to do with spiritism, this
might even become the scientific proof of an afterlife.
And from there, a new science can be erected or can start.
OK, so this was 1952, when Jürgenson was
invited by a Cardinal who was the representative
of the Pope in Sweden, who was of his second wife's family, Nora.
He took, because of the excellence of his
paintings, he took him to the Vatican to reconstruct
the paintings of the underground of this huge
altar that everybody knows about in the church,
in St. Peter's.
And this was, he had not yet started receiving the voices.
His first voice was the 12th of June, 1959.
And when this voice happened, he was already very familiar with the Vatican.
He had become a personal friend of the new Pope, Pope Paul VI.
And of course, in kind of tata-tat conversations,
the Pope told him, he didn't know, about what
had happened to these two Catholic priests
and scientists in the first recording of 1952.
And that's when Jürgenson knew about this, because he never knew that there were other
voices before the ones he was receiving.
He didn't know.
And then, from then on, of course, things
well developed and the Pope always supported
him and was very interested in his research.
I mean, Friedrich Jürgenson's research.
And that's when the Pope, Paul VI, told him that the Catholic Church, through, maybe,
I don't say the correct name, it's the Parapsychological
Commission, whatever of this kind, were also
investigating so-called paranormal phenomena.
And I suppose, also the voices, the Pope told him.
And they used to discuss about this, because
Jürgenson, as you know, Jeff, because you
read the book, was a confessed atheist.
He was an atheist.
He was never a Catholic or even a Christian.
And he says so in his books.
And still, he had this excellent relationship
with the Pope, with the two Popes.
Then he also painted portraits of Paul VI and so on.
So who trusted him totally.
It's a very interesting, very moving relationship
between this atheist, highly intelligent,
highly creative, that Jürgenson is, and the Pope, the chief of the Catholic Church.
Well, the thing that I found most fascinating
about the book is that he went through a very
strange period in his life where he wondered
if he might be becoming schizophrenic, because
he was hearing voices that seemed to be of a telepathic nature.
It's as if the voices from the other side were reaching out to him in multiple ways.
Exactly.
He went through that phase of doubt, of saying, am I becoming crazy?
What is this?
He was listening telepathically, perceiving.
I do not know about listening.
It's not explicit there if it was listening.
The thing was when he listened to the wind,
to water in a cascade and so on, and he would
understand words, yes, which were very possibly already communications.
But this for him, all this was very, very odd, very strange.
And as you said, he doubted that he was sane, mentally sane.
Of course that the skeptics have said many times that Jürgensen was crazy because he
would listen to voices in the noises and the environmental noises and so on.
He was not crazy at all.
A man like that was not crazy.
He went through a period of doubt, and his
communicators tried to, how would I say this,
to penetrate into his being or into his mind, let's put it this way.
Through these telepathic messages, he received several.
It's not unusual for a transcommunicator to, a
good one, a serious one, to receive telepathic
messages.
It's kind of usual.
And then through the radio one day, the feminine
voice who became his guide, kind of his guide,
called Lena, said, turn the radio on, something like this.
And then the voices started coming.
However, as I said, the first one was in Nysund,
his country house, a beautiful place where
I have been, kind of 70 kilometers south of Stockholm.
And he was going for one of his movies to
record, this is a very well-known story, the
chirping of the bird songs, night bird songs.
And that's when he heard this trumpet and a voice that was like his mother's voice.
And that he recognized as his mother's voice, calling him by his pet name, Frida.
And this period of mental doubt was after this,
because there was a pause, then he stopped
everything, and then the telepathic messages
would come and say, don't drop us, don't let
us down, etc., etc., etc.
So of course he went through, because he didn't know that this was a possibility.
Today is a completely different thing.
Everybody knows, or almost everybody, and still
not everybody knows about this possibility,
as you know.
I do, of course, because I have recorded thousands
of voices, but at his time he had no idea,
not even of the Catholic priests, scientists,
not even of Attila Von Szalay and Raymond Bayless
in California, he didn't know that it existed.
So of course he would be doubtful and scared to a certain point, yeah.
So the voice of his mother first came to him in 1959 while he was trying to record
bird songs, I guess because he had an electric plug-in tape recorder.
It was at his home and he put the microphone
out the window to hear the birds when his
mother's voice appeared.
And then by 1963, as I recall, he had written
his own book and given a public press conference
and quite rapidly he became famous all over
Europe, particularly in Sweden, as an advocate
for electronic voices from the dead.
The first press conference, yes, which was,
if I'm not mistaken, 1962, but he called the
press from all over the world, there were even
from the United States, there was a representative
from Life Magazine.
You remember Life Magazine, Jeff, do you?
Oh yes.
So Life Magazine was also there from all over Europe, from all over Europe.
The Swedish were the most sceptical, so Anders Leopold says.
And that's when Anders Leopold, this Swedish
journalist who then became his very close
intimate friend, met him, was during this first press conference, which was attended
by journalists from all over the world, really.
Because nobody knew, nobody knew the voice of the father of one of them, nobody knew
about Attila Von Szalay in his mediumship
cabinet, that he had recorded these bits of voices
and the whistling and so on, nobody knew about this.
So for all of these people, the journalists
from all over the world, it was an impossible
thing, because they had no idea, as it was for Jürgenson, neither of them knew about
that this phenomenon had already hinted, I don't know which word to use, had already
been left some traces in the planet, but it had.
Jürgenson, when he achieved worldwide fame
after that press conference, became probably
at that time, 1962-1963, the foremost proponent
in the world for these electronic voices.
Because yes, of course he was, and then he had followers, many followers.
The most prominent was Konstantin Raudive, who was Raudive, who was a philosopher with
published work, he was a psychologist, he
was a student of Carl Gustav Jung, Jürgenson,
I mean Raudive, and then around Raudive, a
whole circle of scientists, European, Austrian,
Swiss, et cetera, assembled.
And it was Jürgenson, yes, of course it was
Jürgenson, because then he did a second press
conference, during which, I think it was 64, the second one, I think it was.
Anyway, well, this is so many dates, but anyway, there was also a period during the
press conference that they made recordings, and
the journalists were also allowed to record.
And they had results, noisy of course, although
they were in silence, but with voices, that's
what I mean.
So, and with all this, and the support of
the Vatican, and et cetera, and his constant
trips to Italy, and Italian television, and all this, of course he became famous, and
Raudive, who followed him closely, who learned, Raudive learned from Jürgenson.
He was only a pioneer in the sense that he spread the word, Constantine Raudive, when
his book was translated into English, breakthrough, isn't it?
Yes.
But at the time of Jürgenson, of course he went there to visit Jürgenson, learned from
him, and then he started having results like so many others.
Now I gather from the book that Jürgenson collected many, many audio tapes, I think
maybe as many as a thousand, just as you have,
and that there was in effect a museum collection
of all of his tapes that still exists.
It does.
I think it is in Germany, in Germany.
The person who rescued, let's put it this way, rescued Jürgenson's recordings, tapes,
was Carl Michael von Hausswolff, who is a famous
modern musician, kind of noble, in Sweden,
and his father-in-law had been a friend and admirer of Jürgenson, because Carl Michael
von Hausswolff is much younger, he's now a 60-year-old man.
But he was the person who went to the place where he died, because by the time he had
divorced his third wife, Monica, and lived with an old friend, a lady friend, who had
been their friend, of this couple, the Jürgenson
couple's friend, Martha, in the south of Sweden,
and he died there during his sleep.
And Carl Michael von Hausswolff knew of this
man through his father-in-law, who was a very
famous artist in Sweden, and he said, well, his recordings must be there.
And he went there with a friend when he died,
when he died, weeks or so after he died, of
course, and he brought everything with him, all the tapes, thousands, as you said.
And then he started the Jürgenson Foundation,
who ordered the translation of one of his
books, Voices from Space, into English, but the title in English is Radio Transmissions
with the Dead, or something like that.
They offered me this book, the only one translated
into English so far, and the Jürgenson Foundation
offered me this book, which I very much like and
value, and that's how the Jürgenson Foundation
started, and then they had exhibitions, and
they took the tapes to this museum in Germany,
because these countries are all near, isn't
it, they're Sweden, Germany, Austria, Denmark,
and so on, they are all very near, and they intermingle a lot.
So anyway, all the photographs that are in this
book were from Carl Michael von Hausswolff,
who sent them to me to use in the book.
And they are property of the Jürgenson Foundation.
And that's how the tapes were recovered, how they
were saved from annihilation as the president
of the Jürgenson Foundation, who is a wonderful
person, says, he saved, he recovered all the
materials, all Jürgenson's materials, yes, they would be lost without him.
Another fascinating aspect is the communications
apparently coming from Jürgenson since his
death.
I believe he died in 1987, and if I recall correctly, right about the very time of his
funeral, an image of him appeared on a television screen.
Exactly, on the television screen of Claude
Thorlin, who was a very well-known photographer
in Sweden.
Sweden, of course, has always been a little bit of, maybe the Swedish don't like me to
say this, but a little bit of a remote country
in the way that it's in the fringe of Europe,
isn't it, as Portugal is, or Spain even, or Greece.
We are around the core, the heart of Europe, isn't it?
So this Claude Thorlin was a very famous, famous photographer in Sweden, and a very
close friend also of Jürgenson.
They had recordings together in one of those
experiences and reunions that Friedrich Jürgenson
used to have in his house in Stockholm, and the results are here in the book.
And when his funeral was taking place in the

But she had an impression, this lady, who had a

of course, but presentiments, messages, and so on.
And she said, turn on the television, turn on the television, because the day before
She had listened in her mind, not from the
air, to this Channel 4, Channel 4 television.
And Claude Thorlin, who was not medium, he was a photographer, he said, so he turned
on the television, because his wife had told
him, turn on Channel 4, I got this impression.
He turned on the television, but the Channel 4 was blank, there was nothing.
And they waited and said, well, what is this for, he asked there.
Ellen, I think her name was, I can't remember.
Anyway, then suddenly, which later they found
out corresponded to the time of Jürgenson's
funeral in the south of Sweden, this picture,
in a flash of light, appeared on the TV screen
of the Thorlin's.
And then they said, but this is Friedel, this is Friedel's portrait, and so on.
And then, well, they were close friends, as I
said, they had even recorded together, although
Claude Thorlin had started by being a very skeptical person, as everybody, and it was
verified that it was the same hour, exactly
the hour of Jürgenson's funeral in the south
of Sweden.
This photograph, before I forget to tell you,
it's also in the book, there was, you will
know, because that's one of the few who is well known outside of Sweden.
You remember this photographer, Nilsson, Swedish photographer, Nilsson, correct?
The first to photograph a fetus, a human fetus in the womb.
I can't remember his first name, but he is well known, Nilsson.
Okay, you know also, even I knew also.
So one of, because Claude Thorlin was skeptical, and how come this?
And then people started, as usual, saying, no, no, no, there is some trick there, how

And this great photographer, Nilsson, the Swedish one, was one of those who analyzed

Well, he had taken one of these, what's the name of those cameras, that you no longer

And Nilsson, the famous Swedish photographer,
was one of those, besides the technicians

this is true, this is correct, this is true.
So, well, this, I know that this image has been people who do not know, they like to

Ah, this is a false image, and so on.
One of the things that they did was to check
all the television programs in Sweden and
Norway of the time when they recorded, when they photographed this image, and in none

So it was not from a straight television emission.
That was also one of the proofs that were done to this photograph, famous photograph
by now.
Have there been other communications from Jürgenson in addition to this?
As I recall, you mentioned, you heard the name Friedrich Jürgenson on one of your
tapes.
Exactly, I did.
But there were many communications, messages

were followed by Professor Ernst Senkowski
of messages that were authored by Jürgenson,
yes, several, several, apart from that nothing.
If I remember, the text showed up on a computer screen.
Exactly! Adolph Homes' computer screen in Rivenich, Germany.
He received more than 200 computer texts.
Some of those computer texts, it was not even at home.
The computer would start by itself, as mine does sometimes, but I get no messages, but
he had messages.
It was even in a hospital.
Professor Senkowski told me, and still his computer would start itself on, and a very

Senkowski because Adolf Homes was a modest
carpenter who didn't even correctly understand
what the messages said because his instruction,
he was Senkowski, but of rather rudimentary

He would tell Professor Senkowski, who lived
within reach of Rivenich, what is all this

of the, I understand nothing of what it says,

And he preserved these texts and he transcribed

of Adolf Homes' computer texts, more than 200,
that most of the times appeared spontaneously
on Adolf Homes' computer.
Other times they appeared in reply to a question

of paper in Mainz, Germany, and had not communicated

This was an extraordinary period of ITC, the
Harsh- Fischbach and Adolf Homes with his

So it seems there was this enormous flourishing of

Where do things stand today?
Until the 2000, the year 2000, I have there a message that Senkowski brought me, which

Where are things now?

And that's where we are, there is not a great

to 1986 or so until the year 2000.

Now it seems to be disseminated everywhere.

when they used to ask me to leave the radios

I said, why do you want these radios on?
Because I have a soundproof little room and all that, otherwise we could not be in this

Anyway, they always told me, and besides this
is recorded, we are working to be able to

in serious materials we did not have, we did

That journal, at the beginning, I started
